remarks: Induction on the integers from ` M ` to ` N ` inclusive .  The first four hypotheses give us the substitution instances we need; the last two are the basis and the induction step.  (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 31-Mar-2011.)
statement:
fzind.1 $e |- ( x = M -> ( ph <-> ps ) ) $.
fzind.2 $e |- ( x = y -> ( ph <-> ch ) ) $.
fzind.3 $e |- ( x = ( y + 1 ) -> ( ph <-> th ) ) $.
fzind.4 $e |- ( x = K -> ( ph <-> ta ) ) $.
fzind.5 $e |- ( ( M e. ZZ /\ N e. ZZ /\ M <_ N ) -> ps ) $.
fzind.6 $e |- ( ( ( M e. ZZ /\ N e. ZZ ) /\ ( y e. ZZ /\ M <_ y /\ y < N ) ) -> ( ch -> th ) ) $.
fzind $p |- ( ( ( M e. ZZ /\ N e. ZZ ) /\ ( K e. ZZ /\ M <_ K /\ K <_ N ) ) -> ta ) $.
$d K x $.
$d M x y $.
$d N x y $.
$d ch x $.
$d ph y $.
$d ps x $.
$d ta x $.
$d th x $.
